comments.commentBody:
Why not Thorium?
Because the want Highly Enriched Uranium for a nuclear weapon.
It has nothing to do with Republicans.

I hope the Iranians have left themselves an out.

Putin is right: Anything the USA touches abroad turns to rubble and ashes (Iraq, Syria, Lybia, Ukraine, etc., etc.)

The title of this article claims that Iran has agreed. I would love to learn exactly what Iran believes it has agreed to. It appears to be different from what Kerry is claiming.*

****
* "Iran Accuses U.S. of Lying About New Nuke Agreement",
http://freebeacon.com/national-security/iran-accuses-u-s-of-lying-about-...

I agree it's great and not just for parties who worked together on it, but for all the people in the world who are sick and tired of all this warring and just want to live in peace.

As great as that is, I would still find reading anything Dick Cheney had to say too sickening that even with this day's news, I still couldn't feel like I wouldn't want to throw up before I got to the end of the interview.

Cheney's probably fit to be tied and gagged at today's announcement. No doubt we'll be hearing from and seeing that happy, jolly, smiling face of his shortly all over Fox News.

Wrong: it hasn't yet been determined how swiftly or how completely the sanctions will be brought to an end.  And if our Congress decides to throw a wrench in the works the sanctions imposed by our partners in Europe (let alone Russia and China) will almost certainly be lifted immediately.

Poor guy never had a chance against Cary Grant in the best movie of the bunch. And he's also a Chicago connection so he's a pretty good choice.

I can't feel my feet, but my day-before punch list is all punched. Tomorrow is the full moon, so Chag Sameach when it's appropriate and congratulations on not having to eat cardboard for eight days to everyone else.

'...A lot of people simply don't seem to understand that neither the Arab States or Iran feel threatened by Israel, and in spite of what they may say publically, they really don't care much about the existence of Israel.'

I'm one of those people who 'don't seem to understand...' Israel has threatened to bomb Iran, and you are writing that this has nothing to do with Iran wanting nuclear weapons. You think that the Arab people felt it was okay for Israel to take their land, continue to build settlements and bomb Gaza to smithereens?That is the short list. Are you serious when stating that Arab people don't really care about the existence of Israel? What are your sources for this idea?

Of course, the biggest, oldest war is between the Sunnis and the Shia, nevertheless, Israel represents a dangerous interloper devoted to expansion.

The important and arduous agreement undertaken by Obama and Kerry to end Iran's nuclear ambitions is monumental.

Israel is committed to a bunker mentality and that, in part, will be its undoing.
Now is the time to take action, not wait until they breakout with a nuke. Iran wants the sanctions gone and a nuke. This "deal" gives them both.

Once the sanctions are eased, or eliminated, the chances of their re-imposition -- much less the possibility of military strikes -- will become smaller each day.  The probabilities are far higher that today's discussions will increase the volatility of the Middle East (remind me why the Saudis, say, should trust the United States now, and not begin a crash development of a weapon?).  Counting on whatever self-preservation instincts may persist in the Iranian leaders -- much less within their growing list of proxies -- may not be the best strategy.

Framing the ramifications of this agreement in terms of domestic political rivalries is as unfortunate as it is shortsighted. The stakes for us are much higher than which party wins and which party loses elections.

"If Iran is breaching the agreement virtually any president will punish Iran severely." A President who is a Democrat will twist and turn as long as politically possible before determining that Iran is in violation. What severe action the US would undertake other than reimposing sanctions which were at best only effective after considerable time is an open question. A military attack would not be considered. This agreement is far short of what Obama said he would settle for and does not prevent Iran from becoming a nuclear power. Even the NYT article makes that clear. "It could not race to produce a nuclear weapon in less than a year." Start counting. Saudi Arabia is undoubtedly furious. A major realignment in the Middle East will follow.

The Iranians are making a fatal mistake, as they will soon find out. Netanyahu's crocodile tears attest to how dire the consequences will be for Iran.

Washington cannot be trusted — as it has never been about diplomacy and peace. That is, other than with nations that are securely its militarily-occupied economic vassals: Western Europe, Japan, etc.

Once Iran is thoroughly defanged, the usual American-sponsored scenario will play out: Political destabilization and chaos, bombings, and utter ruin. It will be Syria, Lybia, and Ukraine all over again.

Please, wait until the details are at least addressed before you say the issue is not resolved.   All of these points can be addressed and successfully.   Iran wants a modern economy more than it wants a bomb.   I say they should pat themselves on the back every day they keep us out of another conflagration and every day nuclear proliferation is avoided in the Middle East.   Bombing Iran will not solve this problem.  That leaves negotiation as, not the best option, the ONLY option.

Hi Nastassja,

Will Shortz has said that he doesn't believe in the concept of cheating in crosswords. It's your puzzle, so you're allowed to solve it any way you want. And if you learn something new in the process, so much the better, right?,

I think I reached a new level of having to cheat on this one. I don't think there's any way I would have gotten most of those long ones on my own.

Also, being born in '85, "Sister, Sister" sister was a freebie.

"A lot of people simply don't seem to understand that neither the Arab States or Iran feel threatened by Israel, and in spite of what they may say publically, they really don't care much about the existence of Israel."
It is not so much the existence of Israel as the unresolved Israeli-Palestinian conflict that Arab leaders find threatening. Every time that conflict flares up and the Arab public sees the violence on TV, it draws attention to how unrepresentative the autocratic Arab leaders are and how incapable they are of doing much to resolve a conflict about which Arabs as a whole feel very strongly. Failure on that front has done much to undermine the legitimacy of Arab regimes while the repeated bouts of violence have helped stimulate the formation of groups such as Al Qaeda and the Islamic State. Both pose a far greater threat to the Saudi Arabian monarchy than they do to the US.
From another perspective, the example of Israel forging ahead economically while Arab development falls ever further behind is a constant reminder of just how ineffective Arab rulers have been.

If we look at history we'll see that Iran hasn't invaded anybody since Cyrus, just like China. It's amazing how we set up bogeymen to justify the largest defense budget on earth, bigger than everyone else's budget combined. When Iran gets enough boats to invade us I'll worry about them. Ditto China. And Russia.

There is not a shred of evidence that MAD or any of its variations will have any effect on Iran's calculations and plans.  Should Tehran cease to be, are you suggesting that the US would "win" a a nuclear  exchange should we only have traded Los Angeles for it?
You are referring to Iran's "peaceful" Space Launch Vehicle (SLV) that is not a military ICBM capable of delivering nuclear warheads to Europe?

Which interests are those?
Who are those people?

I think keeping Israel safe for at least 25 more years is reasonable. What the PrimeMinister is talking about after that is too forward thinking. It's one to be a visionary and another thing to be living in the future. We are limited to living today in the present.
a positive legacy means something good was accomplished for the country. who wouldn't root for that?

A very nice recipe. I didn't have a bell pepper, so I skipped adding it, though I wouldn't next time. The Thai grocery was out of Holy Basil, so I just used the regular basil I had (which isn't a perfect sub, but it works fine). Looking forward to trying it as written.

If you have access to the ingredients (or reasonable substitutes), I recommend trying it out as a flavorful, quick and easy Thai noodle dish.

Iran has kept the agreements assigned by the NON Proliferation Treaty, and she has been surveilled by the IAEA for years without any violation of the protocols having been discovered. In a way I suppose that should be kind of funny, in a strange way, after all of the misery that has been inflicted upon Persia, and the divisions which have been aggravated by this issue among the American People by Israeli perfidy. In the final analysis what has been gained by this post colonial temper tantrum, which has been directed at an Iran for wanting to chart its own course on relations with the rest of the world, without seeking the approval of Washington or Tel Aviv? I think that we have all been snookered on this dog and pony show, and the foolishness, if the Republicans and Israel have anything to say about it, has only just begun.
If president Obama can get peace with Cuba and Iran done. Plus get Israel - Palestine seriously about a peace treaty, then he deserves a second Nobel Peace Price.

Iran is a more advanced state than most of the Islamic ones in the region. It has well trained engineers, scientists, and military technicians. It has a history of western influence, which also led to the revolution that sent the western oil companies packing.

thanks to the greed and avarice of British Petroleum, along with other western oil companies, Iran became an enemy. They were our friend until they decided they were fed up with oil company domination of their country.

It has taken all these years to get past the western insult to its right to rule its own country. We still have a collection of war mongers who would rather bomb someone than negotiate peace with them. These negotiations are being compare to those with N. Korea, which remains a backward dictatorial violent regime.

As we watch, there will be several members of our congress who will do everything they can to derail this mission. Just listening to their rhetoric leads me to believe, it has nothing to do with keeping the peace, and more to do with preventing Mr. Obama from accomplishing this historic agreement.

He has already made some peace with Cuba, and now Iran. It shows the public just how weak and unproductive the GOPs foreign policies have been, and still are. It is to Iran's advantage to keep the agreements, it is a country that has prospered before, and will again once it can rejoin the western world.
Judging by the current candidates, I would vote for Obama again and again.

Wow...this is huge.  This could be President Obama's greatest legacy,  much like Nixon going to China.  Along with the ACA, ie Obamacare, saving our economy from collapse in 2008, providing steady, intelligent leadership in international affairs,  not least of which is keeping us out of another dumb war in the ME, all these achievements , I believe, will put him in the ranks of our greatest presidents.  When historians look at this record and all the things he tried to do which were thwarted at every turn by the Republicans refusal to work with him for the good of the country,  they will rate him highly.  Bravo, President  Obama.  We will miss you when your term is over.
Great news. Iran should be our key ally in the region, along with Israel.
And the other countries involved in the accord, their politicians are also motivated by creating their own legacies as well? Sounds like a conspiracy to me.
